speaker: National Republican Congressional Committee
vclaim: "Betty Sutton and her Democrats started spending, and now their credit card has reached the limit."
date: stated on May 18, 2011 in a news release:
title: NRCC Rep. Betty Sutton says'spree' of federal debt to the maximum.
text: Our Government receives some of the money it needs by borrowing from foreign governments and other investors. As when your bills become due and your current income cannot match, the United States now needs to borrow more. For money, Congress must first agree on a debt line that is higher than the current limit of $14.294 trillion. It's a lot like living on a credit card and asking the bank for a ceiling, compared to Republicans like it too. In an attack used in some of the differences over 59 other Democrats in the United States House of Representatives, the National Committee of the Republican Congress on 18 May claimed that "Betty Sutton and her Democrats went into a whim of spending and now their credit card has reached the limit." Sutton, from Kobley Township, Ohio, near Akron, you'll probably face the reelection challenger next year. At present, the National Reconciliation Commission is playing the role of the Agency for a potential enemy, accusing Sutton of reckless spending and pushing religion to dangerous levels. But is Sutton's mistake and her democratic colleagues -- is she a good spender -- that the federal credit card has reached the limit? We were struck by this fact because it is worth verifying because of all the other discussions on spending and debt over the past decade, and the way funds flow into and out of the Federal Treasury. Taxes are part of the equation, spending the other. You may recall the tax cuts defended by the Republicans in Congress and former President George W. Bush, the tax cuts that were extended in December for two years under Democratic President Barack Obama. While some economists say that this was necessary to give the economy a kick, it also means that money comes less than tax revenues. Before the last extension, the Congressional Research Service said that Bush's $10 trillion tax cuts had played a major role in the country's annual deficit. Some will argue that tax cuts can in fact be paid for by stimulating economic growth, but Poletti Fuckett has previously found that the budget office of Congress, the Treasury, the Joint Tax Commission and the White House Council of Economic Advisers say that tax cuts lead to lower revenues than they would otherwise have been - even if they stimulate some economic growth. Last year, the Budget Office of Congress stated that, as many in the General Budget Office would like to see it extended permanently, it would cost $3.3 trillion over 10 years and increase the deficit. Then there was the recent economic downturn, which also played a role. The nation is still engaged in wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, with billions of dollars flowing to pay for them. These began during the years of Bush and continued under Obama's rule. The Liberal Centre for Budget and Policy Priorities assumes that only two policies dating back to the Bush administration - tax cuts and wars in Iraq and Afghanistan - accounted for more than $500 billion of the deficit in 2009 "and will account for $7 trillion of the deficit in 2009 until 2019, including associated debt servicing costs." This deficit applies to debt (which, according to the Centre, is a cumulative and increasing deficit). "The Bush-era tax cuts and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan - including associated interest costs - account for nearly half of the public debt expected in 2019 (measured as a share of the economy) if we continue the current policies," the status referred to on 20 May. Or as Ezra Klein, Washington Post Economist, wrote on 23 May, "in other words, cut the financial crisis and the major initiatives of the Bush era from the picture, and we will be in very good shape. In fact, we'll be in good shape." We asked Brian Riddle, the chief budget analyst at the Conservative Heritage Foundation, what he thought of this analysis. It was rude. "In essence, their analysis fails basic statistics," he said in an e-mail. Riddle referred us to his blog, where he wrote, "imagining a basketball team losing 100-98." It would not make sense for their opponent to choose one basket and blame it for 100% of the loss - and to let all the other baskets make significant progress. However, this is what the Centre for Budget and Policy Priorities is doing in the first place." The broader point of Riddle is that "one can choose cherry" any number of spending or tax policies and blame them for the whole problem. The Bank chose to choose tax cuts, wars, stimulus/failures, and economic decline to offset total deficits. It was easy for one to distinguish between social security and medical aid (combined cost: $13 trillion), medical care and net interest costs ($13 trillion), or estimated expenditure ($15 trillion) for blame. There is no mathematical reason to account for the programs selected by CBP while ignoring other costs." Where does that leave us? Each side is cherry choosing numbers. The liberal think tank blames wars, tax cuts, stagnation and associated costs. According to the conservative think tank, the base of blame is larger and involves entitlements as well as discretionary spending. We also narrowed Sutton down, where we spoke with the National Reconciliation Commission; its counterpart, the Democratic Congress Election Campaign Commission; and the Sutton Office. The spokesperson for DNCC Halley Morris Pend Politi Vac 2009 noted that when Bush took office, the national debt was $5.73 trillion. When he left, it was $10.7 trillion. She said, "It's very hard for Gob to argue about the maximum credit card." We referred Sutton's office to a statement made in December when it voted to extend the tax cuts imposed by Bush. These reductions were part of a compromise to continue some form of federal unemployment insurance for unemployed Americans without benefits. "I am very disappointed that the Republicans insisted on adding billions of dollars to the deficit so that they could offer an additional tax cut to the super-rich and an expensive real estate tax to 3,800 millionaires and billionaire property," said Sutton at the time. Finally, the spokesperson for the National Reconciliation Commission, Tori Mazola, told us when Sutton was asked, "You can start with a $1 trillion incentive bill." Then there was the Health Care Reform Bill in 2010. These two alone "get you up to $2 trillion" that the nation didn't get, and they had to be funded, as Mazola said. This was followed by an e-mail indicating Sutton's votes on a large expenditure bill, including an invoice of $1.1 trillion, "which provided an estimated 8 per cent increase in expenditure for the third consecutive year and contained approximately 5,224 allotment marks." The last bill was passed in December 1999 and was not endorsed by any Republicans in the House of Representatives. Sutton also voted at two previous heights in the debt ceiling, as Mazola said, and on a $26.1 billion bill called "Save the State." Others described the latter as a means of assisting state and local governments struggling with economic contraction - a difference in terminology that would help us to reach a conclusion. To say that Sutton pressed the credit card is one way to explain her record, but she ignores all that was spent and borrowed in debt. Was it war and tax cuts from big criminals? Democrats say so. The conservatives differ, as Riddle says it amounts to cherry collection and ignores all spending. Before judging, we have to point out that since 2001, Congress has voted to raise the debt ceiling ten times, according to the Congressional Research Service. Seven of those picnics were under Bush, three under Obama. Sutton certainly voted in favour of spending, so we will not assess the claim of the National Reconciliation Commission in vain. But with cherry-filled trees, the CNR statement was so selective that it barely really made it. Sherwood Brown mentioned on November 30, 2010, in an interview with MSNBC "I understand, this is unemployment insurance. It's not welfare, as many of my Republican colleagues say. You pay for it when you work. You get help when you're not." By Stephen Coffey: 7 December 2010 Editor's Note: This statement was estimated to be barely correct when it was published.
